trans-unit.source: Creating web apps with Django in Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating web apps with Django in Azure

trans-unit.source: A tutorial that introduces you to running a Python web app in Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: A tutorial that introduces you to running a Python web app in Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: Creating web apps with Django in Azure
trans-unit.target: Creating web apps with Django in Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial describes how to get started running Python on [Azure App Service Web Apps](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714).
trans-unit.target: This tutorial describes how to get started running Python on [Azure App Service Web Apps](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=529714).

trans-unit.source: Web Apps provides limited free hosting and rapid deployment, and you can use Python!
trans-unit.target: Web Apps provides limited free hosting and rapid deployment, and you can use Python!

trans-unit.source: As your app grows, you can switch to paid hosting, and you can also integrate with all of the other Azure services.
trans-unit.target: As your app grows, you can switch to paid hosting, and you can also integrate with all of the other Azure services.

trans-unit.source: You will create an application using the Django web framework (see alternate versions of this tutorial for [Flask](web-sites-python-create-deploy-flask-app.md) and [Bottle](web-sites-python-create-deploy-bottle-app.md)).
trans-unit.target: You will create an application using the Django web framework (see alternate versions of this tutorial for [Flask](web-sites-python-create-deploy-flask-app.md) and [Bottle](web-sites-python-create-deploy-bottle-app.md)).

trans-unit.source: You will create the web app from the Azure Marketplace, set up Git deployment, and clone the repository locally.
trans-unit.target: You will create the web app from the Azure Marketplace, set up Git deployment, and clone the repository locally.

trans-unit.source: Then you will run the application locally, make changes, commit and push them to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Then you will run the application locally, make changes, commit and push them to Azure.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial shows how to do this from Windows or Mac/Linux.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial shows how to do this from Windows or Mac/Linux.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to [Try App Service](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=523751), where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: Windows, Mac or Linux
trans-unit.target: Windows, Mac or Linux

trans-unit.source: Python 2.7 or 3.4
trans-unit.target: Python 2.7 or 3.4

trans-unit.source: setuptools, pip, virtualenv (Python 2.7 only)
trans-unit.target: setuptools, pip, virtualenv (Python 2.7 only)

trans-unit.source: Git
trans-unit.target: Git

trans-unit.source: [Python Tools for Visual Studio][] (PTVS) - Note: this is optional
trans-unit.target: [Python Tools for Visual Studio][] (PTVS) - Note: this is optional

trans-unit.source: **Note**: TFS publishing is currently not supported for Python projects.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: TFS publishing is currently not supported for Python projects.

trans-unit.source: Windows
trans-unit.target: Windows

trans-unit.source: If you don't already have Python 2.7 or 3.4 installed (32-bit), we recommend installing [Azure SDK for Python 2.7] or [Azure SDK for Python 3.4] using Web Platform Installer.
trans-unit.target: If you don't already have Python 2.7 or 3.4 installed (32-bit), we recommend installing [Azure SDK for Python 2.7] or [Azure SDK for Python 3.4] using Web Platform Installer.

trans-unit.source: This installs the 32-bit version of Python, setuptools, pip, virtualenv, etc (32-bit Python is what's installed on the Azure host machines).
trans-unit.target: This installs the 32-bit version of Python, setuptools, pip, virtualenv, etc (32-bit Python is what's installed on the Azure host machines).

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can get Python from [python.org].
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can get Python from [python.org].

trans-unit.source: For Git, we recommend [Git for Windows] or [GitHub for Windows].
trans-unit.target: For Git, we recommend [Git for Windows] or [GitHub for Windows].

trans-unit.source: If you use Visual Studio, you can use the integrated Git support.
trans-unit.target: If you use Visual Studio, you can use the integrated Git support.

trans-unit.source: We also recommend installing [Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio].
trans-unit.target: We also recommend installing [Python Tools 2.2 for Visual Studio].

trans-unit.source: This is optional, but if you have [Visual Studio], including the free Visual Studio Community 2013 or Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web, then this will give you a great Python IDE.
trans-unit.target: This is optional, but if you have [Visual Studio], including the free Visual Studio Community 2013 or Visual Studio Express 2013 for Web, then this will give you a great Python IDE.

trans-unit.source: Mac/Linux
trans-unit.target: Mac/Linux

trans-unit.source: You should have Python and Git already installed, but make sure you have either Python 2.7 or 3.4.
trans-unit.target: You should have Python and Git already installed, but make sure you have either Python 2.7 or 3.4.

trans-unit.source: Web App Creation on Portal
trans-unit.target: Web App Creation on Portal

trans-unit.source: The first step in creating your app is to create the web app via the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).
trans-unit.target: The first step in creating your app is to create the web app via the [Azure Portal](https://portal.azure.com).

trans-unit.source: Log into the Azure Portal and click the **NEW** button in the bottom left corner.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Azure Portal and click the **NEW** button in the bottom left corner.

trans-unit.source: Click **Web + Mobile** > **Azure Marketplace** > **Web Apps**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Web + Mobile** > **Azure Marketplace** > **Web Apps**.

trans-unit.source: In the search box, type "python".
trans-unit.target: In the search box, type "python".

trans-unit.source: In the search results, select **Django**, then click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: In the search results, select **Django**, then click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Configure the new Django app, such as creating a new App Service plan and a new resource group for it.
trans-unit.target: Configure the new Django app, such as creating a new App Service plan and a new resource group for it.

trans-unit.source: Then, click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Then, click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.source: Application Overview
trans-unit.target: Application Overview

trans-unit.source: Git repository contents
trans-unit.target: Git repository contents

trans-unit.source: Here's an overview of the files you'll find in the initial Git repository, which we'll clone in the next section.
trans-unit.target: Here's an overview of the files you'll find in the initial Git repository, which we'll clone in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Main sources for the application.
trans-unit.target: Main sources for the application.

trans-unit.source: Consists of 3 pages (index, about, contact) with a master layout.
trans-unit.target: Consists of 3 pages (index, about, contact) with a master layout.

trans-unit.source: Static content and scripts include bootstrap, jquery, modernizr and respond.
trans-unit.target: Static content and scripts include bootstrap, jquery, modernizr and respond.

trans-unit.source: Local management and development server support.
trans-unit.target: Local management and development server support.

trans-unit.source: Use this to run the application locally, synchronize the database, etc.
trans-unit.target: Use this to run the application locally, synchronize the database, etc.

trans-unit.source: Default database.
trans-unit.target: Default database.

trans-unit.source: Includes the necessary tables for the application to run, but does not contain any users (synchronize the database to create a user).
trans-unit.target: Includes the necessary tables for the application to run, but does not contain any users (synchronize the database to create a user).

trans-unit.source: Project files for use with [Python Tools for Visual Studio].
trans-unit.target: Project files for use with [Python Tools for Visual Studio].

trans-unit.source: IIS proxy for virtual environments and PTVS remote debugging support.
trans-unit.target: IIS proxy for virtual environments and PTVS remote debugging support.

trans-unit.source: External packages needed by this application.
trans-unit.target: External packages needed by this application.

trans-unit.source: The deployment script will pip install the packages listed in this file.
trans-unit.target: The deployment script will pip install the packages listed in this file.

trans-unit.source: IIS configuration files.
trans-unit.target: IIS configuration files.

trans-unit.source: The deployment script will use the appropriate web.x.y.config and copy it as web.config.
trans-unit.target: The deployment script will use the appropriate web.x.y.config and copy it as web.config.

trans-unit.source: Optional files - Customizing deployment
trans-unit.target: Optional files - Customizing deployment

trans-unit.source: Optional files - Python runtime
trans-unit.target: Optional files - Python runtime

trans-unit.source: Additional files on server
trans-unit.target: Additional files on server

trans-unit.source: Some files exist on the server but are not added to the git repository.
trans-unit.target: Some files exist on the server but are not added to the git repository.

trans-unit.source: These are created by the deployment script.
trans-unit.target: These are created by the deployment script.

trans-unit.source: IIS configuration file.
trans-unit.target: IIS configuration file.

trans-unit.source: Created from web.x.y.config on every deployment.
trans-unit.target: Created from web.x.y.config on every deployment.

trans-unit.source: Python virtual environment.
trans-unit.target: Python virtual environment.

trans-unit.source: Created during deployment if a compatible virtual environment doesn't already exist on the web app.
trans-unit.target: Created during deployment if a compatible virtual environment doesn't already exist on the web app.

trans-unit.source: Packages listed in requirements.txt are pip installed, but pip will skip installation if the packages are already installed.
trans-unit.target: Packages listed in requirements.txt are pip installed, but pip will skip installation if the packages are already installed.

trans-unit.source: The next 3 sections describe how to proceed with the web app development under 3 different environments:
trans-unit.target: The next 3 sections describe how to proceed with the web app development under 3 different environments:

trans-unit.source: Windows, with Python Tools for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Windows, with Python Tools for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Windows, with command line
trans-unit.target: Windows, with command line

trans-unit.source: Mac/Linux, with command line
trans-unit.target: Mac/Linux, with command line

trans-unit.source: Web app development - Windows - Python Tools for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Web app development - Windows - Python Tools for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: Clone the repository
trans-unit.target: Clone the repository

trans-unit.source: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal.
trans-unit.target: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.source: Open the solution file (.sln) that is included in the root of the repository.
trans-unit.target: Open the solution file (.sln) that is included in the root of the repository.

trans-unit.source: Create virtual environment
trans-unit.target: Create virtual environment

trans-unit.source: Now we'll create a virtual environment for local development.
trans-unit.target: Now we'll create a virtual environment for local development.

trans-unit.source: Right-click on **Python Environments** select **Add Virtual Environment...**.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on **Python Environments** select **Add Virtual Environment...**.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the name of the environment is `env`.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the name of the environment is `env`.

trans-unit.source: Select the base interpreter.
trans-unit.target: Select the base interpreter.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the **Application Settings** blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).
trans-unit.target: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the **Application Settings** blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).

trans-unit.source: Make sure the option to download and install packages is checked.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the option to download and install packages is checked.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**.

trans-unit.source: This will create the virtual environment, and install dependencies listed in requirements.txt.
trans-unit.target: This will create the virtual environment, and install dependencies listed in requirements.txt.

trans-unit.source: Create a superuser
trans-unit.target: Create a superuser

trans-unit.source: The database included with the application does not have any superuser defined.
trans-unit.target: The database included with the application does not have any superuser defined.

trans-unit.source: In order to use the sign-in functionality in the application, or the Django admin interface (if you decide to enable it), you'll need to create a superuser.
trans-unit.target: In order to use the sign-in functionality in the application, or the Django admin interface (if you decide to enable it), you'll need to create a superuser.

trans-unit.source: Run this from the command-line from your project folder:
trans-unit.target: Run this from the command-line from your project folder:

trans-unit.source: Follow the prompts to set the user name, password, etc.
trans-unit.target: Follow the prompts to set the user name, password, etc.

trans-unit.source: Run using development server
trans-unit.target: Run using development server

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to start debugging, and your web browser will open automatically to the page running locally.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to start debugging, and your web browser will open automatically to the page running locally.

trans-unit.source: You can set breakpoints in the sources, use the watch windows, etc. See the [Python Tools for Visual Studio Documentation] for more information on the various features.
trans-unit.target: You can set breakpoints in the sources, use the watch windows, etc. See the [Python Tools for Visual Studio Documentation] for more information on the various features.

trans-unit.source: Make changes
trans-unit.target: Make changes

trans-unit.source: Now you can experiment by making changes to the application sources and/or templates.
trans-unit.target: Now you can experiment by making changes to the application sources and/or templates.

trans-unit.source: After you've tested your changes, commit them to the Git repository:
trans-unit.target: After you've tested your changes, commit them to the Git repository:

trans-unit.source: Install more packages
trans-unit.target: Install more packages

trans-unit.source: Your application may have dependencies beyond Python and Django.
trans-unit.target: Your application may have dependencies beyond Python and Django.

trans-unit.source: You can install additional packages using pip.
trans-unit.target: You can install additional packages using pip.

trans-unit.source: To install a package, right-click on the virtual environment and select **Install Python Package**.
trans-unit.target: To install a package, right-click on the virtual environment and select **Install Python Package**.

trans-unit.source: For example, to install the Azure SDK for Python, which gives you access to Azure storage, service bus and other Azure services, enter `azure`:
trans-unit.target: For example, to install the Azure SDK for Python, which gives you access to Azure storage, service bus and other Azure services, enter `azure`:

trans-unit.source: Right-click on the virtual environment and select **Generate requirements.txt** to update requirements.txt.
trans-unit.target: Right-click on the virtual environment and select **Generate requirements.txt** to update requirements.txt.

trans-unit.source: Then, commit the changes to requirements.txt to the Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Then, commit the changes to requirements.txt to the Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Deploy to Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy to Azure

trans-unit.source: To trigger a deployment, click on **Sync** or **Push**.
trans-unit.target: To trigger a deployment, click on **Sync** or **Push**.

trans-unit.source: Sync does both a push and a pull.
trans-unit.target: Sync does both a push and a pull.

trans-unit.source: The first deployment will take some time, as it will create a virtual environment, install packages, etc.
trans-unit.target: The first deployment will take some time, as it will create a virtual environment, install packages, etc.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio doesn't show the progress of the deployment.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio doesn't show the progress of the deployment.

trans-unit.source: If you'd like to review the output, see the section on [Troubleshooting - Deployment](#troubleshooting-deployment).
trans-unit.target: If you'd like to review the output, see the section on [Troubleshooting - Deployment](#troubleshooting-deployment).

trans-unit.source: Browse to the Azure URL to view your changes.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the Azure URL to view your changes.

trans-unit.source: Web app development - Windows - command line
trans-unit.target: Web app development - Windows - command line

trans-unit.source: Clone the repository
trans-unit.target: Clone the repository

trans-unit.source: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal, and add the Azure repository as a remote.
trans-unit.target: First, clone the repository using the URL provided on the Azure Portal, and add the Azure repository as a remote.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service](web-sites-publish-source-control.md).

trans-unit.target: Create virtual environment

trans-unit.source: We'll create a new virtual environment for development purposes (do not add it to the repository).
trans-unit.target: We'll create a new virtual environment for development purposes (do not add it to the repository).

trans-unit.source: Virtual environments in Python are not relocatable, so every developer working on the application will create their own locally.
trans-unit.target: Virtual environments in Python are not relocatable, so every developer working on the application will create their own locally.

trans-unit.source: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).
trans-unit.target: Make sure to use the same version of Python that is selected for your web app (in runtime.txt or the Application Settings blade of your web app in the Azure Portal).

trans-unit.target: You can use the requirements.txt file at the root of the repository to install the packages in your virtual environment:

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting - Package Installation
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting - Package Installation

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting - Virtual Environment
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting - Virtual Environment

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting - Static Files
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting - Static Files

trans-unit.source: Django has the concept of collecting static files.
trans-unit.target: Django has the concept of collecting static files.

trans-unit.source: This takes all the static files from their original location and copies them to a single folder.
trans-unit.target: This takes all the static files from their original location and copies them to a single folder.

trans-unit.source: For this application, they are copied to `/static`.
trans-unit.target: For this application, they are copied to `/static`.

trans-unit.source: This is done because static files may come from different Django 'apps'.
trans-unit.target: This is done because static files may come from different Django 'apps'.

trans-unit.source: For example, the static files from the Django admin interfaces are located in a Django library subfolder in the virtual environment.
trans-unit.target: For example, the static files from the Django admin interfaces are located in a Django library subfolder in the virtual environment.

trans-unit.source: Static files defined by this application are located in `/app/static`.
trans-unit.target: Static files defined by this application are located in `/app/static`.

trans-unit.source: As you use more Django 'apps', you'll have static files located in multiple places.
trans-unit.target: As you use more Django 'apps', you'll have static files located in multiple places.

trans-unit.source: When running the application in debug mode, the application serves the static files from their original location.
trans-unit.target: When running the application in debug mode, the application serves the static files from their original location.

trans-unit.source: When running the application in release mode, the application does **not** serve the static files.
trans-unit.target: When running the application in release mode, the application does **not** serve the static files.

trans-unit.source: It is the responsibility of the web server to serve the files.
trans-unit.target: It is the responsibility of the web server to serve the files.

trans-unit.source: For this application, IIS will serve the static files from `/static`.
trans-unit.target: For this application, IIS will serve the static files from `/static`.

trans-unit.source: The collection of static files is done automatically as part of the deployment script, clearing previously collected files.
trans-unit.target: The collection of static files is done automatically as part of the deployment script, clearing previously collected files.

trans-unit.source: This means the collection occurs on every deployment, slowing down deployment a bit, but it ensures that obsolete files won't be available, avoiding a potential security issue.
trans-unit.target: This means the collection occurs on every deployment, slowing down deployment a bit, but it ensures that obsolete files won't be available, avoiding a potential security issue.

trans-unit.source: If you want to skip collection of static files for your Django application:
trans-unit.target: If you want to skip collection of static files for your Django application:

trans-unit.source: Then you'll need to do the collection manually on your local machine:
trans-unit.target: Then you'll need to do the collection manually on your local machine:

trans-unit.source: Then remove the `\static` folder from `.gitignore` and add it to the Git repository.
trans-unit.target: Then remove the `\static` folder from `.gitignore` and add it to the Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Troubleshooting - Settings
trans-unit.target: Troubleshooting - Settings

trans-unit.source: Various settings for the application can be changed in `DjangoWebProject/settings.py`.
trans-unit.target: Various settings for the application can be changed in `DjangoWebProject/settings.py`.

trans-unit.source: For developer convenience, debug mode is enabled.
trans-unit.target: For developer convenience, debug mode is enabled.

trans-unit.source: One nice side effect of that is you'll be able to see images and other static content when running locally, without having to collect static files.
trans-unit.target: One nice side effect of that is you'll be able to see images and other static content when running locally, without having to collect static files.

trans-unit.source: To disable debug mode:
trans-unit.target: To disable debug mode:

trans-unit.source: When debug is disabled, the value for `ALLOWED_HOSTS` needs to be updated to include the Azure host name.
trans-unit.target: When debug is disabled, the value for `ALLOWED_HOSTS` needs to be updated to include the Azure host name.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: or to enable any:
trans-unit.target: or to enable any:

trans-unit.source: In practice, you may want to do something more complex to deal with switching between debug and release mode, and getting the host name.
trans-unit.target: In practice, you may want to do something more complex to deal with switching between debug and release mode, and getting the host name.

trans-unit.source: You can set environment variables through the Azure portal **CONFIGURE** page, in the **app settings** section.
trans-unit.target: You can set environment variables through the Azure portal **CONFIGURE** page, in the **app settings** section.

trans-unit.source: This can be useful for setting values that you may not want to appear in the sources (connection strings, passwords, etc), or that you want to set differently between Azure and your local machine.
trans-unit.target: This can be useful for setting values that you may not want to appear in the sources (connection strings, passwords, etc), or that you want to set differently between Azure and your local machine.

trans-unit.source: In `settings.py`, you can query the environment variables using `os.getenv`.
trans-unit.target: In `settings.py`, you can query the environment variables using `os.getenv`.

trans-unit.source: Using a Database
trans-unit.target: Using a Database

trans-unit.source: The database that is included with the application is a sqlite database.
trans-unit.target: The database that is included with the application is a sqlite database.

trans-unit.source: This is a convenient and useful default database to use for development, as it requires almost no setup.
trans-unit.target: This is a convenient and useful default database to use for development, as it requires almost no setup.

trans-unit.source: The database is stored in the db.sqlite3 file in the project folder.
trans-unit.target: The database is stored in the db.sqlite3 file in the project folder.

trans-unit.source: Azure provides database services which are easy to use from a Django application.
trans-unit.target: Azure provides database services which are easy to use from a Django application.

trans-unit.source: Tutorials for using [SQL Database] and [MySQL] from a Django application show the steps necessary to create the database service, change the database settings in `DjangoWebProject/settings.py`, and the libraries required to install.
trans-unit.target: Tutorials for using [SQL Database] and [MySQL] from a Django application show the steps necessary to create the database service, change the database settings in `DjangoWebProject/settings.py`, and the libraries required to install.

trans-unit.source: Of course, if you prefer to manage your own database servers, you can do so using Windows or Linux virtual machines running on Azure.
trans-unit.target: Of course, if you prefer to manage your own database servers, you can do so using Windows or Linux virtual machines running on Azure.

trans-unit.source: Django Admin Interface
trans-unit.target: Django Admin Interface

trans-unit.source: Once you start building your models, you'll want to populate the database with some data.
trans-unit.target: Once you start building your models, you'll want to populate the database with some data.

trans-unit.source: An easy way to do add and edit content interactively is to use the Django administration interface.
trans-unit.target: An easy way to do add and edit content interactively is to use the Django administration interface.

trans-unit.source: The code for the admin interface is commented out in the application sources, but it's clearly marked so you can easily enable it (search for 'admin').
trans-unit.target: The code for the admin interface is commented out in the application sources, but it's clearly marked so you can easily enable it (search for 'admin').

trans-unit.source: After it's enabled, synchronize the database, run the application and navigate to `/admin`.
trans-unit.target: After it's enabled, synchronize the database, run the application and navigate to `/admin`.
